content.text: State the volume of the water in the measuring cylinder
A student adds 20 drops of water to the water that is in the measuring cylinder in Fig. 1.1. The new volume of water in the measuring cylinder is \(25 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the average volume of one drop of water
average volume of one drop =   .........  \(cm^3\)
A student has a measuring cylinder and a small, irregularly shaped piece of metal. The piece of metal can easily fit into the measuring cylinder
Describe how the student can use the measuring cylinder and some water to find the volume of the metal
Fig. 1.1 shows a measuring cylinder containing some water
Calculate the resultant horizontal force on the car
size of force =   .........  N
direction
Using the information in Fig. 2.2, state the time taken to travel \(100 \text{m}\)
time to travel \(100 \text{m} =\)   .........  s
The car takes \(12.8 \text{s}\) to travel the next \(200 \text{m}\)
Calculate the average speed of the car for this 200 m
average speed =   .........  m/s
A student uses a digital stop-watch to measure the time for the car to travel \(100 \text{m}\)
Fig. 2.2 shows the time reading on the stop-watch
Fig. 2.2
Fig. 2.3 shows the speedâ€“time graph for another car
Calculate the distance travelled by this car between time \(= 2.0s\) and time \(= 6.0s\)
distance travelled =   .........  m

Fig. 2.1 (not to scale)
The sailor applies a force of \(200\mathrm{N}\) at a distance of \(30\mathrm{cm}\) from the pivot in the winch, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Calculate the moment of this force about the pivot
moment of force =   .........  \(N \text{cm}\)
Describe two useful energy transfers when the sailor uses the winch to raise the sail
Describe one non-useful energy transfer when the sailor uses the winch to raise the sail
A sailor uses a winch to raise a sail on a boat. Fig. 3.1 shows the sailor turning the winch
A student has an object with a mass of \(5.0 \text{kg}\)
Calculate the weight of the object
weight of object =   .........  N
The student lifts the \(5.0\mathrm{kg}\) object from the floor onto a table. He does \(75\mathrm{J}\) of work on the object in lifting it onto the table
State the amount of gravitational potential energy gained by the object due to being lifted onto the table
gravitational potential energy gained by object = ................................................. J
The weight of a table is \(280 \text{N}\). The table has four legs. The area of each table leg in contact with the floor is \(18 \text{cm}^2\)
Calculate the pressure of the table on the floor. Give the correct unit
pressure on the floor =   .........  unit   .........
Atmospheric pressure is \(756 \text{mm}\) of mercury
Calculate the pressure of the gas in the gas bottle
pressure of gas =   .........  mm of mercury
State the name of the measuring device shown in Fig. 5.1
Describe how the gas exerts a pressure on the cylinder
Use your ideas about molecules
The piston moves and increases the volume occupied by the gas. The temperature of the gas remains constant. Fig. 5.3 shows the new position of the piston
State and explain what happens to the pressure of the gas on the cylinder
Some gas is trapped in a cylinder fitted with a moveable piston. Fig. 5.2 shows the arrangement
An engineer measures the pressure of the gas in a gas bottle. Fig. 5.1 shows the measuring device he uses, connected to the gas bottle
State the name of the effect shown in Fig. 6.1
When the wave passes from deep water to shallow water, two of its properties change
Describe how one of these properties changes
property
change in property
The waves move from deep water to shallow water. Fig. 6.1 shows the wavefronts
The student notes that it takes 10 s to produce 25 complete waves in the water tank
Calculate the frequency of the waves
frequency of waves =   .........  Hz
State one other example of a transverse wave
Describe the vibration of particles in a transverse wave
Waves on the surface of water are transverse waves
A student investigates wave properties. He uses waves on the surface of a tank of water to show the properties
A student has a bar magnet and a metal bar with ends X and Y. The student moves each pole of the bar magnet, in turn, to be close to end X of the metal bar
Fig. 7.1 and Fig. 7.2 show the force between the magnet and the bar in each case
State and explain what you can deduce about the metal bar
Use the information shown in Fig. 7.1 and Fig. 7.2
Fig. 7.3 shows two bar magnets on a piece of card
Fig. 7.3
Describe an experiment to show the pattern of the magnetic field between the bar magnets
Using standard symbols, draw a circuit diagram for the student's circuit
When the switch is closed there is a current in the circuit
State the name of the particles flowing in the metal wire
The current in the \(15\Omega\) resistor in Fig. 8.1 is \(0.40\mathrm{A}\) when the switch is closed
Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across the \(15\Omega\) resistor
Fig. 8.1 shows an electric circuit set up by a student
Give a reason why the plug includes a fuse
Explain how a fuse works
The mains plug for the transformer contains a fuse
The mains input (primary) potential difference (p.d.) to the transformer is \(230\mathrm{V}\) a.c
The number of turns on the input (primary) coil is 314. The number of turns on the output (secondary) coil is 150
Calculate the output (secondary) p.d. from the transformer
State a suitable material for the core of the transformer
State a suitable material for the primary and secondary coils of the transformer
Explain how Fig. 9.2 shows a step-down transformer
Fig. 9.2 shows an outline of the transformer
Fig. 9.1 shows a transformer used on a building site
\(\alpha\) (alpha)-particles, \(\beta\) (beta)-particles and \(\gamma\) (gamma)-rays have different characteristics
Complete Table 10.1 by indicating with a tick \((\checkmark)\) the correct type of radiation for each characteristic. The first row is done for you
The nucleus of an isotope of plutonium has 94 protons and 147 neutrons. The chemical symbol for plutonium is Pu
Write the nuclide notation that describes this nucleus
A sample contains \(8.0 \times 10^{12}\) atoms of a radioactive isotope of plutonium
The half-life of this isotope of plutonium is 14 years
Calculate the number of atoms of this isotope of plutonium remaining in the sample after 28 years
number of atoms of plutonium remaining =
